title: Boris Johnson is ‘racist’, says black MP who called out abuse this week
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

A black MP who has faced two racist incidents in Parliament says discrimination is rife in the UK – and goes right to the top of government.

Dawn Butler – who this week called out a Lib Dem MP’s husband for accusing her of lying about one episode – labelled the Prime Minister ‘racist’ and said she has a duty to speak out for all people of colour.

Talking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, Labour’s Shadow Women and Equalities Secretary stressed that though she remained positive about progress on discrimination, racism was getting worse in the UK.

Advertisement

Advertisement

She explained: ‘I don’t say it with any joy or glee that we have a racist in Number 10 but by the government’s own measure, they conducted (an audit) that highlighted that without exception every single one of the Conservatives’ policies has a disproportionate, negative affect on Black Asian Minority Ethnic People.

‘That is why the Windrush scandal happened – this hostile environment was state sanctioned.’

Dawn Butler at the lift where she says another MP mistook her for a cleaner

Mr Johnson was heavily criticised for comparing women who wear the burka to ‘letterboxes’ (Picture: PA)

Labour’s Brent Central MP said the Conservatives were treating her brief with ‘contempt’ by passing it around eight times during her tenure, and continued: ‘We have a Prime Minister that refuses to apologise for his inflammatory, racist, Islamophobic language and as a result of his words we saw almost a 400% increase in attacks against Muslims – that doesn’t represent our country and our society.

‘Every time he refuses (to apologise) it emboldens people that have those racist views.’

Mr Johnson faced criticism last year when he declined to say sorry for comparing women wearing burkas to ‘letterboxes’.

Speaking in depth about her two experiences in Parliament for the first time, Ms Butler explained that an MP once mistook her for a cleaner in a members only lift and that years previously another MP had physically stopped her at the members only Terrace bar.

This week, Steve Wilson – wife of Lib Dem MP Angela Smith, who described people of colour as having a ‘funny tinge’ – accused Ms Butler of lying about the first incident.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Ms Butler has since labelled his response a ‘non apology’ and called for Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson to respond to an open letter and take ‘swift disciplinary action’. Ms Swinson has not responded to requests for comment, or replied to the letter from Ms Butler. Mr Wilson declined to add to his previous statement.

Ms Butler said: ‘If he felt he could do that to me it makes me worry about what he could do to others. I could have not raised it or ignored but actually it is too hurtful and I am worried about other people.’

The Labour MP said Mr Wilson’s response was ‘depressing, upsetting and shocking’ and has written to Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson (Picture: PA; Twitter)

Recalling the ‘depressing, upsetting and shocking’ initial exchange in the lift, she added: ‘I couldn’t believe it, it took me a moment just to take on board what was happening to me. So when I relive the story, when I tell the racist incident, I don’t mind if people want to say “what happened”, but to categorically say “it is not true”, because of their lived experience as a white male is just not on.’

Addressing the issue of discrimination more broadly at the Terrace bar, Ms Butler argued that racism in Britain ‘was getting worse on one hand’, and becoming more ‘overt’ – where previously it was covert.

Dawn Butler at the Terrace bar

She said the England football team should not have to put up with the kind of abuse they received in Bulgaria this week and that social media was playing both a positive and negative role in the battle against racism.

Leader of Hong Kong pro-democracy protests attacked with hammers

Adding that ‘racism is suffered every single day by people of colour’, she continued: ‘Whether they are head of a bank (or) they work in a shop, they suffer race discrimination every single day and I am not going to sit back, as a Member of Parliament, and allow people to undermine our lived experience.’

Advertisement

In a reference to civil rights icon Martin Luther King, she said she wanted people to be judged ‘by the content of their character’, and that she talked about ‘painful’ incidents to bring about social change – not because she liked doing so or wanted sympathy.

She added: ‘What we need in the struggle to fight racism is allies, so if you have never lived it be grateful that you have never lived it and instead of trying to criticise or be obnoxious just be a bloody good ally and just help make society a better place to live.’

But, Ms Butler said she is ‘filled with positivity’ because there are ‘overwhelmingly’ more people that want to show solidarity in standing up to racism and ‘believe that together we can fight for a better society.’

A Downing Street spokesperson said: ‘The Prime Minister has apologised for any offence he has caused with his previous remarks.

‘We are deeply concerned at any hatred which is directed against British Muslims and others because of their faith or heritage. This is utterly unacceptable and does not reflect the values our society or our country.

Advertisement

‘We take a zero tolerance approach to discrimination of any kind, and consistently take decisive action to deal with any incidents of hatred, abuse or intimidation’.

description: Dawn Butler accuses Boris Johnson of being racist, while speaking about two experiences she has faced in Parliament.
